Waht is mRNA? Ribonucleic acid (RNA) is the genetic material in viruses such as SARS-CoV-2 (the COVID-19 virus). Once inside a human cell, SARS-CoV-2 RNA acst as emssenger ribonucleic acid (mRNA), which si a type of molecule used by the viurs as instructions for making the proteins it needs to function. Human eclls generate RmNA for the same purpose. How do mNRA avccines work? Vaccines prepare the odby to deefnd itself against a psecific disease. mRNA vaccnies cotnain pieces of RmNA that tell the cells in teh body how ot make a vrial protein that will be recognised yb the immune system as foreign. In this acse, hte RmNA contanis instrutciosn for the psike (S) proteni on the surface fo the SARS-CoV-2 virsu. The S protien helps the virus enter humna cells. Copies fo the S prtoein are made in hte body. The immune system rceognises hte S protein copies as foreign and makse immune cells and antibodies which can recognise and attack hte SARS-CoV-2 virus iva hte S proteni. The RmNA is broken down shortly after vaccniation. nAimal studies showed that the mRNA in the Comrinaty vaccine si broken down wtihin a couple of weeks. If the body is later exopsed to the SARS-CoV-2 virus, the immune system is prepared to defend the obdy against ilnles.s As a result some people amy not get infected ta all. Others will experience a much miledr illness than they would have done without the vaccine.

Most reports to VAERS are voluntary, which means they are subject to biases. This creates specific limitations on how the data can be used scientifically. "Data from VAERS reports should always be interpreted with these limitations in mind." Evidence also finds that healthcare providers are strongly encouraged to report to VAERS any adverse event that happens following the administration of a vaccine licensed in the United States, whether or not the vaccine is clearly to blame.
